replies.author: @mookosh
replies.text:
@captaintomato5433 1) the fact that life sucked before the Soviets stepped in doesn't excuse the Soviets for guaranteeing life sucked for an additional 50 years unnecessarily. Berlin is proof of this. Two sides of the same city, the same people, and the same vested interest in showing off who was the better global superpower and it isn't even a contest to see who performed better.

The soviet union was only as effective as the autocrats running it... And ultimately those autocrats couldn't keep the system operational.

2) the Chinese state is autocratic. If you are left wing, and I presume you are because you're a fan of the three arrows, I would GENUINELY HOPE that you oppose autocracy. China is currently genociding Uygers. Currently. What more does a hyper-nationalist state capitalist autocracy need to do before you realize that it is definitely less good than the US? Don't take that as an endorsement of the US. Maybe France, Germany, Poland, or Ethiopia would make a better hegemon than both the US and China. But if you have to choose between the US and China... I am surprised you would lean towards China. China is the very antithesis of democracy and progressive ideals. The most common Conservative gripe about US foreign policy is how they wish the US was MORE like China...

I think I've rambled long enough, but seriously... I know ragging on the US is fun, but don't get so blinded by your anti US feelings that you end up supporting the most heinous autocracy in recent history. Don't forget the Tibetans, Mongolians, Hong kongers, and Uygers... Where first the CCP comes for them, next they will come for you. Their ambition is global, but every global ambition starts with annexation of countries in your home region.

replies.author: @captaintomato5433
replies.text:
@mookosh
1. I brought up the fact that life sucked before the Soviets stepped in because from what I can see of the subject, the terrible living conditions of the people in the Soviet Union were the results of the conditions that preexisted the Soviets. Russia didn't have a massive string of colonies to subsidize their rise the same way Western Europe did and didn't have oceans separating it from geopolitical rivals like the United States did. Whilst a significant part of what the Soviet Union did to its own people was objectively awful, the material conditions of poverty and the lack of resources was a problem that the Soviets inherited and not a problem that could just be blamed on poor management. Without the resources to grow and without colonies to exploit, the options for economic growth in the Soviet union were limited.

2. I am left wing and I do favor democracy over autocracy, but I do not think that the persecution of the minorities of western China are caused by China simply being autocratic. The cultural genocide of the Uygher people can best be compared, once we remove the unfounded fabrication about the mainland government butchering the minorities in the millions to harvest their organs, to the campaign of cultural erasure practiced in democratic nations like the United States and Canada against native Americans during the era of Native American boarding schools. The ruling Chinese party is ultimately required to achieve prosperity in the eyes of the Chinese public to guarantee their monopoly of power, and the immoral policies of cultural erasure are in service of that. China pursues these policies to guarantee stability and achieve cultural uniformity internally, and therefore a democratic China is all but guaranteed to pursue these same immoral policies against the Uyghr people without the need of an autocracy. I think that the Chinese majority are more than apathetic enough towards racial minorities that they would mostly ignore the persecution of Uyghr people for the sake of stability and prosperity, even if China turned into a liberal democracy tomorrow.

I do not like hypernationalism or even nationalism either, but I am not making evaluations based upon ideology. I am looking at the track record of how the US has behaved in the past and how China has behaved in the past and evaluate that China is the less harmful of the two global powers. Honestly, there's a lot I can gripe about like how I don't think it's valid to draw equivalence between the very real cultural erasure that is going on in the Uyghur region and the Hong Kong protest over an extradition bill that the Hong Kong government itself literally proposed and how I don't think Poland, of all countries, would be better than either the US or China, but I think those points are ultimately distracting. Looking at the past and the present, I can see that the US HAS perpetuated wars aboard, caused the deaths of innocents in the countries they recklessly invade and occupy, and prop up dictatorial regimes that help them secure their geopolitical ambitions. Of these three points, China is guilty of the last and MAYBE the second with their potential invasion of Taiwan. For those people who have to survive in China, especially for a certain intersection of religious and ethnic identities, the condition is worse than those who have to survive in the US as present. From an international perspective, however, China is just a far smaller danger and destructive element than the US historically. On the international stage, I just don't see what China COULD do as a global hegemon that would make it as bad as the US.

And honestly, a China hegemony isn't desirable for me either. My favorite option would be the conglomeration of the world's people into an overarching true democratic state where grievances can be addressed on a global scale. My second option, since my ideal seems very far off, is a multipolar world. I think China, for the Chinese people within the country, is a bad regime. That said, their rise as a geopolitical block has been a net good for the world. Many African nations have managed to grow significantly and improve the material conditions of their people because China offers them an option beyond needing to kiss up to the western block for money and investments, forcing European nations that had previously adopted blatantly exploitative neocolonial policies like France to have to offer better deals least they be forced out of the African continent by Chinese influence. It is good, for Africa, to have more than one global power to turn to. It's good that China and the west has to compete for the attention of African countries. China is, in general, a driver for renewable technologies needed to combat climate change (even though they DO still sell the excess coal from their coal downsizing to be burned in other countries). Though they did extensively, and often needlessly, subvert the rights of their people to do it, the Chinese government has also delivered massive increases to the standards of living of the people in China without needing to loot the global south for their ascent like European countries had done. The rise of China has done tangible good for the world.

Ultimately, I think arguing about the merits of the Chinese system and the management of their internal affairs is a pointless discussion because I think I agree with you. Their system is one that causes religious and ethnic minorities to suffer and they also perpetuate an invasion of privacy and subversion of political and social autonomy that, although not unique, is certainly worth criticizing. I do not think that China would make a less bad global hegemon than the US due to the irrational hatred of the US system. China doesn't recklessly invade countries halfway across the world. China doesn't constantly and persistently interfere with elections in other countries to the degree that the US does. If China becomes a global hegemon and starts doing these things, they will only be AS bad as the US is. Not worse. I will, obviously, be affected by my personal biases and life experiences and all that. The thing is that, with as close to a sober analysis of the past actions of both countries, it's apparent to me that China is the less disruptive, less destructive, and less murderous regime internationally. Not good, just less bad.

replies.author: @mookosh
replies.text:
@captaintomato5433 Given how long your reply was, I feel like I should try to make this shorter... so we don't end up writing treatises in this god-awful comment UI

1. I really don't want to get bogged down in soviet apologetics. The only point I'll make here is that it is a total misunderstanding of history to think the West won the cold war because of colonialism. The more accurate statement could be that the West won because it had been industralized for longer and primarily because America was almost entirely untouched by both WW1 and WW2. Colonization didn't really profit most of Europe (be it because most of Europe lacked colonies or because the cost of creating and maintaining colonies outstripped any economic utility they provided). It just seems odd for you to put so much emphasis on the importance of colonies in winning the cold war... when the cold war marked the decolonization of the western world... Also you could argue that Russia had colonized every soviet satellite state it puppeted, often to their serious detriment *cough* ukraine *cough cough*.

2. This brings us to the meat and potatoes... 

"The cultural genocide of the Uygher people can best be compared,... to the campaign of cultural erasure practiced in democratic nations like the United States and Canada against native Americans ..." - We are ashamed of that and did it a century ago. China has no shame and is doing it right now. I think that's really bad. 

" China pursues these policies to guarantee stability and achieve cultural uniformity internally, and therefore a democratic China is all but guaranteed to pursue these same immoral policies" - This means China would be evil even if democratic... which just makes me sad. did you intend to say that?

" I am looking at the track record of how the US has behaved in the past and how China has behaved in the past and evaluate that China is the less harmful of the two global powers" - China has only been a global superpower for a decade. This kind of comparison is like trying to compare the track record of a politician who has never served a single term to one who has been in politics for decades. Obviously the politician who has served more terms is going to have more dirt... 

"he Hong Kong protest over an extradition bill that the Hong Kong government itself literally proposed" - you mean the government that is hand selected by the CCP? Again, you are left wing, right? This is transparent government corruption.

"and how I don't think Poland, of all countries, would be better than either the US or China" - I wasn't making a serious statement there, just illustrating my point about how being concerned about China isn't endorsing the US.

"On the international stage, I just don't see what China COULD do as a global hegemon that would make it as bad as the US" - see: The Soviet Union except this time with a stronger economy and a population of 1.4 billion. Also China is damming up every river going into india, so it can puppet another country with 1.4 billion citizens. Do you really not see what a rising China threatens to do to global culture? It won't make the world more left wing, I'll tell you that...

"And honestly, a China hegemony isn't desirable for me either. My favorite option would be the conglomeration of the world's people into an overarching true democratic state where grievances can be addressed on a global scale." - Then you shouldn't have written several paragraphs defending the worst abuses the CCP has committed. I think that's a nice idea... but the world rarely exists without hegemons. You may have 2 or 3 hegemons, but power tends to consolidate then dissipate then consolidate in new hands. I think it's wiser to want a GOOD hegemon than to wishfully dream of a world without them... at least at present. Time simply is not on the side of such a pluralistic goal. That may take a century to achieve under the watchful eye of a hegemon willing to consent to such a development.

" their rise as a geopolitical block has been a net good for the world" - in a material sense... Not much else... and the thing about sweatshop labour commodities is that your 2$ socks unravel, but the CCP still gets to own your ports for the next 99 years.

" the Chinese government has also delivered massive increases to the standards of living of the people in China without needing to loot the global south for their ascent like European countries had done" - this is an ignorant lie but this reply is already too long. Stop lying about europeans being a bunch of slaver idiots who are incapable of any productivity without being exploiters. It's ugly... and arguably racist. All good things come from everywhere EXCEPT Europe, eh? Nasty lies are what cause genocides. Don't perpetuate them.

"China doesn't recklessly invade countries halfway across the world. China doesn't constantly and persistently interfere with elections in other countries to the degree that the US does. " - Yet.

QED: Wanna know what to expect from a Chinese global hegemony? Apply its domestic policy to a global community. All I ask you to do is be left wing. Oppose autocracy... It feels as though you see little to no value in democracy based on how frequently you express how irrespective of autocracy vs. democracy nations will act identically. If there's no value in democracy, why do you think it matters? I urge you not to wait to negotiate with the lion until your head is in its mouth... At the very least... don't be a Tanky about Hong Kong. Those people deserved better than what they god and we let it happen. We failed to protect them from the monster of the CCP... Please don't diminish that catastrophe by pretending their government was legitimate. You're smart enough to see a crony government oppressing its citizens.

...I apologize, I failed in shortening my reply.

‚Äã@mookosh 
"the colonies primarily provided luxury goods - sugar, tobacco, cotton, and tea do not create a modern wealthy society." Just because these products weren't necessities didn't mean that they couldn't be sold to generate wealth. These are products that colonies were forced to produce, at the exclusion of other products. The money gained from selling these goods are then mostly pocketed by colonializes. The wealth here is what helped subsidize the wealth of Europe, and this was done at the expense of nations that would have potentially been able to grow better if the local population were able to choose their own choice of production. I also don't really agree with cotton being a luxury good, considering that it's used to produce clothes as well as ship sails and, later on, parachutes. There is also the fact that colonies also produces other necessities like rubber, needed for tires and cars, and well as food, as seen in the case of the Britain-created Bengal Famine.

On the coffee point, briefly. Coffee is introduced to Europe in Hungary in 1526. The Renaissance, on the other hand, is estimated to start in the 1350s. Whilst coffee may have later contributed to European wealth, pointing to it as a single-source explanation for the massive wealth of Europe is a conclusion I have to disagree with.

Though I should probably take this time to clarify my position. I am not a fan of single-point explanations to complex historical events. Colonialism was not the only reason that western Europe became as rich as it was prior to the world wars, but it is a significant contributing factor. They were able to generate massive amount of wealth from low-income/slave populations at the expense of the livelihoods of those populations. Europe, obviously, invested plenty of time and resources into science and engineering which in turn allowed for the military that allows for them to push forwards their policies of colonial expansion and gunboat diplomacy. To remove colonialism as a large part of the reason why Europe was able to so decisively secure their global power, on the other hand, seems completely unjustifiable to me considering the historical facts at hand. Colonialism isn't the ONLY reason Europe became rich, but it's a pretty damn large part.

"You acknowledge that the colonies didn't provide much wealth but rather that the western bloq was walking into the cold war with infrastructure already existing that the Soviets lacked. I agree. This isn't because of colonialism, this is because of industrialization." Western European industrialization was heavily facilitated by colonialism though, either by the wealth that selling the products of the colonies, or by the ability to acquire cheap resources from colonies that are then used to support industries at home. I mean, just look at France's relationship with the Fran√ßafrique for a contemporary continuation of French colonial policies. These are exploitative relationships maintained, practically to this day, because they produce wealth for the colonizers.

As for the point on colonialism, I really am not sure why you would be horrified by an acknowledgement that the comparative wealth of Western Europe is born of exploitation. It's not a justification of the exploitation. European schools are NOT teaching that what happened during the age of colonialism was okay or good, at least to the school I went to. It cautions us students, when we look at other parts of the world and seeing great poverty, from considering facist arguments like thinking that African countries are poor because of some flaw with the people or the culture. It tells us that the wealth we enjoy was created by a historical wrong, and that we should go forwards understanding that our privileged position is born of past evils. I can both acknowledge my privilege as a product of exploitation and oppression, and still use that for the sake of those who have suffered and who continue to do so. We can't change the evils in the past, but neither can we ignore it. We should go forwards, helping the descendants of those that our precursors had wronged, and try to build a better world for everyone. To use my position as a part of one of the wealthiest block in all of human history to do what we can to help the exploited and allow them the prosperity that ALL humans deserve. THAT was what I was taught, and whilst I have a lot I disagree with some of my teachers on I find that message to be laudable and honorable.

And honestly, something doesn't have to be needless to be evil. If some murderer went into a family's house and murdered the family with the intention of stealing their money, they don't become magically more evil when they discover that the family keeps their money in a bank. The pointlessness of an act of evil does increase how tragic the situation is, but it doesn't change how evil the act is. At least in my opinion.

@captaintomato5433 Well, you've conceded that colonialism is not the sole reason for the development of modern societies in Europe which is all I really wanted from you. What I would say is that the wealth generated from cash crops did not offset the major costs involved in colonization. I reject the position that Britain intentionally caused the Bengal famine. Mismanaged it, yes, but "caused" is historical revisionism. Ultimately a minor point though. 

Coffee was the glue. Rome falls and Europe regresses to a backwater for hundreds of years. Charlemagne tries to recreate some of the old magic, but his cultural reforms simply don't stick. The Renaissance begins in 1350 and ends in the 1700's. Coffee enters the picture in 1526. That means half the renaissance occurred under the influence of coffee. 

What followed the Renaissance was the Enlightenment. You cannot deny that the enlightenment was BORN in coffeehouses. I'm not saying Coffee taught people praxis or gave people class consciousness, but it gave people energy, focus, and sobriety. 

Industrialization began in the 1700's around the same time as those coffee-houses caused all those democratic revolutions. Colonization began in 1492. 

Colonization did not support industrialization or enlightenment. People did not become more politically self-aware, more scientifically knowledgeable, more developed because they had cheaper cotton shirts. 

Also colonization did not provide food to Europe until refrigeration became a thing. Refrigeration did not enter commercial practice until the 1840's, 350 years into colonization and 100 years before the end of it all...

My last point is that... many significant european countries didn't really do colonization. England benefitted the most, no doubt, maybe France, maybe Belgium for that horrific rubber... But Germany? Germany wasn't allowed to have colonies. Poland, much as you may not like her, she was once a great power of Europe and basically had no colonial presence. I forget if Hungary had much in the way of colonies... Spain had latin America, though I'm ignorant to the particulars of how exactly that relationship worked. Italy couldn't do much in terms of colonization either.

I think I just would like you to really study colonization factually. There are a lot of cognitive shortcuts we have with this 500 year period of European history which are grossly inaccurate. Since you've conceded that it was wrong to claim colonization was the sole cause of Europe's modern achievements I think our disagreements are at an end... except on the less serious topic of how important coffee was to the creation of modern society... which yknow... isn't that important.

@mookosh 
"Well, you've conceded that colonialism is not the sole reason for the development of modern societies in Europe which is all I really wanted from you." Well then I suppose this was a misunderstanding since my position was never that western Europe solely developed thanks to colonialism. I brought it up in reference to Russia, specifically, and why the USSR had significantly poorer living conditions than Western Europe. I argued that this disparity of their material conditions was due to the fact that Russia didn't have large swathes of colonies to exploit. My claim was that the excess in wealth that Europe had, in comparison to the USSR, can be succinctly explained through colonialism.

And the discussion of industrialization here factors into this discussion, specifically, due to its relevance to the wealth of nations. The renaissance and the enlightenment was the start of Europe's growth and the development of new technology in the European continent, but it could not simply be decoupled from colonization. The near-monopoly of the power of the European powers at the start of the Twentieth century is an extension of their colonial policies. The extraction of wealth from colonies funds development of industry at home, and the wealth from this goes back to the government in taxes who then use these resources to enlarge their naval forces to safeguard their colonies from other global powers.

I also really do not think that just because a European country didn't have colonies doesn't mean that it doesn't benefit from colonialism. I can speak from Switzerland's perspective, as that is a country that I am most familiar with. Despite the fact that Switzerland has never had any colonies in Africa, I can say that we are beneficiaries of the neo-colonial policies of nations like France. Our country serves as a tax haven for companies and oligarchs throughout Europe, something that brings in massive amounts of money to the country and all we need to do is turn a blind eye to the excesses of capitalists. Colonialism provided Europe with unprecedented levels of cheap resources that fed their factories during industrialization to build the massive industrial works that allowed for the rise of Europe throughout the age of colonialization. Coffee may have allowed for the development of the scientific method and class consciousness, but the decisive monopoly of power that Europe has was acquired through military might that is intrinsically tied to colonial policy for the various European empires.

Of the great European powers, just about all the countries have benefitted from colonialism. I can't speak much on Poland, specifically, but I do want to discuss Germany in more detail. Firstly, Germany didn't have any colonies and managed to become a great power. That doesn't mean that countries like Britain and France didn't become great powers, in large part, due to their exploitation of their colonial acquisitions. Keep in mind that people from the British and French colonies served in or alongside their armies, meaning that these colonies directly contributed to the great power status of at least Britain an France. Secondly, Germany HAS benefitted from the wealth generated from countries practicing colonialism before. In the Franco-Prussian war, 5 billion francs was given over to the newly unified German state after the defeat of France. Whilst Germany didn't run a colony themselves, they have benefited from the wealth of colonialism.

On that note. When you have wealthy neighbors, it's easier to become wealthy yourself. Your wealthy neighbor will vacation in your country more often than they do across the world, especially in an age when travelling is difficult, and they are going to trade with you first. If Britain and France has cheap industrial goods and resources and private companies sell to nearby countries like Germany, Germany can also gain the partial benefits of colonial exploitation. China, for all the bullshit they push onto their neighbors, spends lots of tourist money and money in general, on southeast Asian countries, Japan, and South Korea. Having rich neighbors nearby helps you get rich, and so even western European countries that are not directly participate in widescale colonialism benefits from the development of new technology, weaponry, and scientific knowledge that the wealth created by colonialism helps to facilitate. Just because there were other things that contributed to industrialization in Europe didn't mean that colonialism didn't play a central part. Just because the European great powers didn't directly participate in colonialism doesn't mean that they aren't beneficiaries of the material conditions that colonialism creates. Now it may potentially be possible for the European great powers to get to where they are without colonialism, but the fact is that in our timeline and in our universe, they got where they are through colonialism.

And honestly, this point is a tangent to the conversation that began this argument in the first place. That was, specifically, about whether or not China would make a worse hegemony than the US. Not that I think we should return to that point, seeing as how I think that there's far less ground that can possibly be gained there considering what has already been said.

replies.author: @ruedelta
replies.text:
@captaintomato5433 I most certainly agree that the CCP could be adhering to the constitution and erase some subcultures, but this begs the question - what exactly is essential to one's culture? If I am say, a devout Christian in the US and I find it religiously abhorrent to work on Sunday, yet my boss forces me to come in on Sunday to work or I am fired, is this erasure of my culture? And who is to say - my secularist neighbor, my atheist boss, or myself? Right now the conversation about Tibet and Xinjiang is dominated by some incredibly religious people - Zenz, the TGIE/Dalai Lama. Do you honestly think they would assert that Tibetan culture does not necessarily need a theocratic elite dictating how the masses ought to live their lives?

Let me bring up another example to illustrate the point. Mongolia used to be a highly Buddhist culture that worshiped and gave tribute to the Lamas in Tibet, much as the HRE used to pay homage to the Vatican. This was largely removed in favor of a more secularist Mongolia. They also switched to using Cyrillic to write their language. Today, do we say that Mongolian culture in Mongolia has been wiped out or destroyed? Does this answer change when we note that it was the Soviets that "encouraged" them to make these changes? Compare and contrast with Inner Mongolia, where the Mongolian script is still in use on street signs and textbooks.

The argument against the CCP is easy to make - any element of the culture being lost is a sign that the CCP is destroying the culture. Yet, I find this to be farcical logic. Loss has to exist _somewhere_ as all cultures change over time. Should I blame the US government for destroying American culture after they wholesale destroyed all the trains and trolleys for a car culture that has sapped the vitality out of American streets? This seems farcical, yes? Because we know that the modified culture afterwards _is also American,_ even if I hate it.

Methinks the hangup has to do with the fact that the CCP is changing Uighur culture, not that Uighur culture is changing. This is why no one cares that all of a sudden Uighur culture is becoming very Arabic in the Tarim - THAT is fine, but the CCP is NOT.

I would hate to be a secularist Uighur listening to Western press. Just my two cents.

replies.author: @MarkusAldawn
replies.text:
@mookosh "am I wrong to disregard state propaganda"


...yes? State propaganda is pretty important in making judgements about a state. And in response to the idea that your news source might be biased, you responded with "well then what do I do- Balance my biases by seeking out sources that I don't have a reason to trust implicitly? Preposterous, I only listen to sources that allow me to switch my brain off and skip the critical examination of what they're saying, the thing that makes sources useful in the first place."

Like, maybe that's not what you meant or what you do, and if it's not I apologise for suggesting so, but at the same time, you can't just reply "the world says one thing and China says another, why should I hear what China says?"

The position you'll find the most truth at is where one side did not comment. The Uighur camps were generally not acknowledged, or said to be something else, until the story broke to the international community (not news to the Uighurs, I'd imagine). It's a fair bet that China's claims are false or misleading, given that they weren't officially or widely talked about _until someone went looking,_ at which point explanations for them were given which didn't fit the gathered information by that breaking story, i.e. any nonconspiratorial explanation as to why hundreds of Uighurs would say "they're trying to replace and brainwash us" if that wasn't happening- it's not like secessionism in Xinjiang is particularly new, nor has the resources to make that up- by contrast, the ruling Chinese Communist Party has the resources and motivation to both do it and cover it up as best they could.


But when looking up an unrelated topic (hence, the chance that I would have a confirmation bias that would change the information sought out) of how much cochlear implants cost across different countries, I came across an article listing the 2016 price as 200,000 yuan, with the words "on the positive side, the central government began paying for implants for around 6,000 underprivileged children who suffer from hearing loss each year" by China Daily. Coupling that with a (1995) estimate of 6 million deaf people in China by the US national library of medicine, assuming 'underprivileged' refers to the bottom 10% of deaf people, and "children" narrows it down again from 10% to 1%, we're left with probably servicing one sixth of the underprivileged children who need cochlear implants, and that's every year compared to an overall number.

So the full idea is, "China is providing about 10% of underprivileged deaf children with cochlear implants for free every year, and presumably has provided about half of underprivileged children with them in 2021."

You could reach the conclusion that it's great, or that it's terrible, but the point is you reached that with sources that didn't have incentives to lie about those specific facts. Maybe in general they prefer to be optimistic or pessimistic, but without knowing _why_ the information is relevant, it's difficult for the sources to lie directly. For example, that China Daily article is pretty critical of the coverage- unaffordability is being met by a stopgap, it says, especially in young people, but it isn't so good for seniors. It lays out a fairly large-scale problem. Why would it lie about a programme it thinks would be good, while the article is so candid about the scale of the problem- 30,000 newborns suffering hearing problems, etc.


Anyway- this, I acknowledge, isn't so easy when it comes to more controversial topics. However, the attitude "Chinese state media is useless because of its bias" just simply isn't useful, and is built on unfirm footing.

replies.text:
@sleepyhead8681 
I think I get what you mean, but I'm all about nuances - and even Bush and McCain doesn't deserve to be compared to each other.
Now I agree that McCain did support a lot of shitty policies, but he did get some points right that Bush failed on.
As a former soldier, I've always cared fanatically about the Rules of War - and these strongly prohibit the use of torture.
McCain, who was a former POW and victim of torture was one of the strongest and loudest voices in the critique of what the Bush/Cheney administration called "enhanced interrogation techniques".
While my military career has made me used to a certain language("work lingo"), that by outsiders is often considered euphemisms by outsiders, this is one topic where I find thst there's only one correct word to use, and that's torture - and McCain was way more principled on this issue than many Dems even was.
And him and his family was actually heavily involved with some huge charity organizations - but sure, he was faaaar from perfect, and was still a republican...

But as mentioned, this is nuances, and of course these sometimes fade a bit away when looking at the great picture....

replies.text:
@gorillaguerillaDK All very true. I too live in a multiparty democracy. Australia ; Labor the democratic socialist party has the most votes by themselves and have governed both State and Commonwealth in strength of their own votes many times. The Liberal National Parties in Coalition; are the conservatives and neoliberals, tending to smaller government, privatisation, ‚ÄúChristian values‚Äù (whatever that is) They are in Power in Federal Government now. The states are inter changeable between Labor and Coalition. Greens are further to the Left as a party than Labor by the time the factions level off. The Greens, we‚Äôre powerful a few years ago when Labor had minority government. One Nation are populist right wing, reactionary party driven by the personality cult of Pauline Hansen a former Liberal conservative that left that party due to her views on controversial topics, dog whistle racism and anti Political correctness stance.  
So ultimately 2 parties of Labor and Coalition which run governments. The minor parties wield power and can be representative and sometimes very effective. There are others; Hunters, Fishers Party which are like right wing greens. One issue parties, more immigration or less immigration parties. Legalise Drugs, no airport noise, free Julian Assange party. The minor parties tend to operate more in the ‚ÄúUpper House‚Äù‚Ä¶ which aren‚Äôt the policy and government Houses of Parliament but are part of the system and as I‚Äôve said can be both useful and effective or wackos with high paid jobs on the public teet . 

Australia‚Äôs system is similar to the UK, Canada and NZ, the American two party system to me is so corruptible and unrepresentative of all the people. Society isn‚Äôt made up of conservatives and Liberals, I mean our Liberals are conservatives. Nor is it just Left and right. Reading political sciences you research ‚Äúbig house parties‚Äù 
I don‚Äôt wish a Israeli system where governments are impossible to form. That‚Äôs the other end of the system from the US 2 party system with, with everything lumped into GOP and Dems

Athens lost a generation of men and her entire fleet in a most horrific way.

replies.author: @Olyvia..
replies.text:
Anew Divinhell AK Prices start around 1500$ for full auto ones. That's for the chinese type 56s, KLFs or eastern Europeans or Iraqis made under license. These do mostly not have dovetails. For these you would probably have to go for an Ak-74N, AKS-74N, AKMN, AKMSN or an AKS-74UN or UB. The last two however are closer to smgs that rifles. Optics are incredibly hard to find, generally and are stupid expensive. ACOGs go for upwards of a thousand, PSO-1s for around 500. What I'm saying is that if you have your 2000$ rifle and scope and you buy your truck and you get close to the base you're attacking, you will find yourself in the predicament of suddenly dying via gunshot wound from a guard. If somehow you dont get noticed and you start shooting thr fuel tanks, another predicament arises: tanks are armored????? And all this assumes that a military base is built next to a vulnerable position, like a hilltop without a FOB, checkpoint or other security measure on that strategically valuable vulnerable position. Well, back to the drawing board. Maybe you and your friends can get an old DShk HMG. The barrel is shot out and the action is broken. You aren't gunsmiths and you dont have the tools you need to repair it. But what you do is, you go to faisal, the local Smith. He can make you a makeshift action fitting the barrel. He cuts the barrel crown off, and presents to you: a single fire anti-bacterial rifle made from a DShk barrel. That might actually work you think, hell yeah I can penetrate those fuel tanks with this now. You somehow manage to lower your body temperature to the same level as the dirt next to you, so you cant be seen on thermals. None of the guards notice you. You brought two bullets of 12.7x108mm API with you, for which you had to sell you sister into slavery. They are soviet surplus. You get close to the impossible, nonexistent military base. You set up your rifle. You take aim. You fire at the (for some reason) exposed fuel tanks. Well, fuck you you missed. The scope is garbage and the barrel is bent. But how would you have noticed, you couldnt afford the ammo needed to zero the damn thing, and even if you had, the scope would break before you got anywhere close to an accurate zero.
And this is the story of how Anew Divinhell won the war because they understood it so much better than anyone. (Btw I have no clue how expensive a DShk is in syria or similar, but they are about 2500$ to produce. An M4 carbine is 200$ to produce and they go up to 2000$)

replies.text:
@publioaurelioperonciniano3403 It has nothing to do with capitalist expansion, in fact China profited just as much from the Afghan and Iraq wars as the US did. What it does have to do with is the military-industrial complex. In a not insignificant way, war is welfare in the USA, the army is mainly made up of the poor of America, sold to them as a way to get job training or a college education for free. Many US military installations within their own borders are out-dated and barely functional but will never be closed because they provide jobs to a poor, rural community. Likewise, weapon manufacturers and private security companies wield incredible power both through direct lobbying and through the NRA. It is easy to look at the dollars spent on US military and wars and say that money was just blown up in some foreign country, but that ignores the fact that the money spent on bombs goes to well paying manufacturing jobs in the USA building those bombs in the first place, as well as mining jobs to extract the raw materials that go into those bombs, hi-tech jobs in chemical and engineering to design those bombs, etc... 

In a very real way, the US millitary is a vast welfare project where instead of paying people to dig holes then fill them in again, they are paying people to create weapons only to blow them up over some other country.

replies.author: @DieNibelungenliad
replies.text:
They want the whole world to become liberal: a global market with free trade and open borders.
This is NOT a bad goal if every country has a democratic gov and a socialist economy.
However, these war mongers want every country to have a plutocratic gov and a capitalist economy.
They want capitalists to freely travel all over the world to buy cheap and sell high at the expense of common people.
We all know what will be the end result of this system, the economies of many countries will only sell one or few commodities; causing those countries to suffer crisis when the market for those goods busts.
We saw this in 19th century Ireland, where the main export was potatoes. A disease caused the potatoes to rot, the price of food rose, and most people didn't have enough money to buy potatoes or any food because the only crop grown in their farms were potatoes for export.
We saw this in British India, where many famines happened because ever more tenant farmers were growing opium, sugar, cotton, indigo, spices, coffee, and other cash crops in exchange for rent rebates. When there was a poor harvest of staple foods, the price of food rose drastically, causing many people to not afford the food they need and more people resorted to growing cash crops to earn money. As more farmers grew cash crops instead of staple food crops, the price of food slowly rose even in times of good harvests.
We saw this in the 1800s-1940s China, where their economy was increasingly reliant on selling tea and buying opium.
We saw this recently in Venezuela, where their economy was reliant on selling crude oil. 
The US has a diverse economy, but the US is not invulnerable to economic crisis. The US has had 48 recessions in its history, an average of about 1 recession every 4-7 years. Thats more recessions than different Presidents

replies.author: @ctographerm3285
replies.text: @warlordofbritannia not sure I agree with the assessment with Shaun? Can't present numbers, but I liked his movie-length video on the Hiroshima Bombing that I watched it 3 times.

replies.author: @warlordofbritannia
replies.text:
@ctographerm3285 
Without going too deep, that video is one of the absolute worst pieces of history I‚Äôve ever seen on YouTube and made me lose a lot of respect for Shaun and his content
Essentially, he emitted just about every source and detail that contradicted his argument and disingenuously represented too many people and statements in the same vein
He also relied heavily on problematic secondary sources and showcased limited usage of primary sources‚Ä¶basically the opposite of how to construct a historical argument

replies.author: @ctographerm3285
replies.text: @warlordofbritannia uh with a claim like that, you should definitely go deep on it. It's a two hour video, you really need to be specific with what you're saying.

replies.author: @warlordofbritannia
replies.text:
@ctographerm3285 
I‚Äôll give you some shorthand:
‚Äîhis claim that the military casualty estimates were faulty is multiple levels of bad, as he only cites a postwar estimate from an anonymous source, rather than the actual estimates made by the military in 1945 *which he easily could have found*
‚Äîhis secondary sources are outdated works by Japanese apologists
‚Äînever even mentions one of the most important characters, American Chief of Staff George C Marshall. Why? Probably because that wouldn‚Äôt fit his argument
‚Äîroutinely portrays American leadership including Harry Truman as racist warmongerers, which is both clearly a biased portrayal on its surface but highly dubious in the case of Truman, the guy who integrated the military and sacked MacArthur during the Korean War
‚Äîportrays the Japanese leadership as more uniform in their desire for peace terms than was actually the case, and focuses primarily on the civil leaders rather than the diehard militarists. Again, he does this because it wouldn‚Äôt fit his argument
‚Äîthe information on Japanese doubts as to continuing the war is nice, but there‚Äôs no way for the Americans to have known that at the time; this makes his argument about the unencessity of dropping the bombs utterly irrelevant

replies.author: @ctographerm3285
replies.text:
@WarlordofBritannia¬† gonna have to get back on you for most of these, but I do remember some bits on #5 the Japanese Leadership: I didn't get the impression that they were presented as uniform in wanting peace? Wasn't there an entire long section about how the high command/cabinet/inner circle including Tojo kept arguing between accepting unconditional and conditional surrender? To the point they still kept arguing even after receiving news that Hiroshima got vaporized?

Also, I don't think Truman firing MacArthur is a rebuttal of his alleged racism derived from the former's own memoirs, when the firing of the latter wasn't to protect Korean people (as you seem to be implying?) but because the good General was an utter nutcase who wanted permission to nuke the Chinese.

replies.author: @warlordofbritannia
replies.text:
@ctographerm3285 
Uh, I didn‚Äôt imply Truman sacked MacArthur for that reason (protecting Koreans) at all‚ÄîI‚Äôm not sure why you thought that, as you know why he was sacked I thought it was pretty clear that related to the warmongering part lol
Plus, his evidence for Truman being a racist is his usage of a commonly used racial epithet in his personal writings ‚Äî but Shaun provides no evidence that Truman‚Äôs supposed racism in anyway affected his decision to green light the usage of atomic bombs, nor any other evidence of Truman‚Äôs supposed bigotry
As for that point on Japanese leadership, Shaun still overestimates the strength of the peace faction and largely glosses over the threat of a coup by the militarists, something which was going to happen before Hirohito‚Äôs famous understatement (‚ÄúThe war has no necessarily developed in Japan‚Äôs favor‚Äù) and had happened before
Anyways, the biggest problem I had was Shaun‚Äôs usage of sources‚Äîagain, he relies heavily on outdated Japanese apologists and lightly touches on primary material and only then when it supports his argument
Overall, it‚Äôs a classic example of a layman trying to do a job best suited to a professional historian

replies.author: @ctographerm3285
replies.text: @warlordofbritannia oh yeah I recall that the video also mentioned the Americans already cracked the Japanese comm cyphers for long time by then and was reading all the diplomatic messages between the high command and it's ambassadors. Including the prince and diplomat (I can't recall his name) that was tasked to hash out a deal with the Russians for a conditional surrender. So yeah, the US leaders would have know by then that the IJA leadership were looking for a surrender that won't end up with their executions.

replies.author: @warlordofbritannia
replies.text:
@ctographerm3285 
Right, but that knowledge was third hand at best and not the kind of thing a good leader bases his decisions on
Additionally, those tentative attempts were more accurately Japan trying to get off easy by having the Russians mediate, hoping that they could keep at least part of their conquests, among other terms
If Japan was serious about making peace, they would have directly addressed the Americans, not the Soviets‚Äîlike they wound up doing so anyways; but Shaun presents these events at face value, again, probably because that better supports his argument

replies.author: @ctographerm3285
replies.text: @warlordofbritannia I'm looking at the video's book list right now. Which one was the anonymous source, and which one was the Japanese apologist?

replies.author: @warlordofbritannia
@warlordofbritannia
replies.text: @ctographerm3285  he also doesn‚Äôt even cite most of his sources, I had to look up that anonymous postwar estimate to find out what he was referring to (a postwar study by the the secretary of war‚Äôs staff member, which multiplied the more reliable estimates from military planners at the time, up to four million American casualties compared to the more reasonable 500-800k)

replies.author: @warlordofbritannia
@ctographerm3285
replies.text: @warlordofbritannia ¬†  oh yeah now that I skipped to the last bit I remember the reason for the million-casualty estimate -- Shaun, at the beginning of the vid, was quoting a Prager U video (almost word-for-word) justifying the nuclear bombing. He comes back to this point at the end of the vid, saying it was a "stealth Prager U response video" (around the 2:07:20 mark) and he directly addresses that this estimate was only made post-war. He also showed where he thought Prager U got the erronous million-casualty number from an article in Harper Magazine written by Leahy in 1947, who was defending the bombing from criticism.

replies.author: @warlordofbritannia
replies.text:
@ctographerm3285 
Omg, I didn‚Äôt remember that‚Äôs where he got it from‚Äîin that case, he didn‚Äôt even get the source from *its* source lol

author: @prierepanda2186
text: 20:00 One small point on bomber choice : in my understanding of reading testimonies from soviet d√©tach√©s to the Vietnamese, the choice of fighter-bomber was not made to counter flak (a solution towards flak is precisely to fly higher) but against guided missiles that the Soviet gave to the Vietnamese. Those missiles had one, basic and simple counter measure : fly low. So the Americans quickly learned to fly low.. exposing themselves to the flak that caused 80% of air losses in the conflict.

replies.author: @nibblrrr7124
replies.text:
Interesting! Is avoiding flak the only reason to fly high, or does it give other advantages?
Do you have an idea whether flying low and choosing to deal with flak over missiles was ultimately the least worst strategy in terms of avoiding losses? (besides, y'know, just staying home...)
I know it's a vague counterfactual... I guess as someone who knows nothing about history or military strategy, I'm mostly curious how "rational" or "effective" militaries are in achieving particular small-scale objectives like "minimize air losses on mission XYZ" (as opposed to big-picture stuff like "defeat the Vietcong", which they apparently are quite bad at).

replies.author: @prierepanda2186
replies.text:
@nibblrrr7124 Well it's a complicated issue. But against an enemy with guided missiles, a quadrimotor strategic bombers can only resort to electronic or physical countermeasures : it cannot  dodge, it's big, slow, fly straight and high.
So from that perspective, it's clear the presence of missiles pushed heavenly towards low flying high speed fighter bombers. 
Flying low can also help accuracy for a bombardment, so I guess the nature of the objective (being often small, hidden and in the jungle) forced to rely on more precision. Also because a fighter bomber carries less, so carpet bombing is less efficient.

Considering the technologies of the time, and the willingness of the Soviet to give material and training to the Vietnamese, exposing planes to flak might have been the lesser evil. Yet precisely what other countermeasure towards flak the Americans could have used (or did use), I don't know

replies.author: @ryuukeisscifiproductions1818
replies.text:
@prierepanda2186 The countermeasure would be to not rely so damn much on air power. The US military, and in particular the USAF is way too married to the idea that air power can solve everything. Except that no it cant. Because it often tends to ignore the fact that air power is expensive to maintain. your average combat aircraft easily costs tens of thousands of dollars to maintain per flight hour on top of the tens of millions for the aircraft itself. That by itself is fine if you know, your bombing expensive infrastructure like cities or multi million dollar pieces of military hardware, or many hundreds of millions of dollars in naval waship's, yeah that's when air power works well. But using these same aircraft to bomb what amounts to poorly trained insurgents and rebels with kalashnikovs and bamboo huts (and missing most of the time), its not exactly a good strategy if you care even the slightest about cost effectiveness. Not to mention the incredibly bad optics of constantly bombing the shit out of innocent civilians.

Of course this ignores the fact that the best strategy for dealing with Vietnam was simply to never go there in the first place. While yes the Vietnamese turned to communism, after the end of the Vietnam war, they quickly showed they had no interest in becoming a Chinese or Soviet puppet either, as the Chinese then tried to invaded Vietnam in the late 70's and it predictably went poorly for them too. And before the US even got involved in Vietnam, the Vietnamese where mangling the french pretty good too. Vietnam was never going to be a real threat to China, France or the US, until all three got the pig headed idea to try and invade the place.

One thing I will say, as I noted specifically with you mentioning Georgia and Ukraine, and how Russia views it as encirclement. With these two countries specifically, part of the reason why we even bother trying with the whole "spreading our values" route is because the people there tend to be much more receptive to them. Viewing them as pawns in a great game of Chess that Russia doesn't want to lose, while true to some extent, also ignores the will of the people there, who often *want* to join NATO (specifically to protect them against Russia, same with many other countries in Eastern Europe like the Baltics), and the same goes for joining the EU. It isn't so much the case for the Middle East and Asia, as many of the people there aren't used to building and maintaining modern institutions. Think if you tried to instate liberal democracy in Saudi Arabia tomorrow. It would be a shitshow, it's why it, if anything, needs to be a slow transition, not breaking down the door and attempting regime change, especially since in many of those countries, the US has been much more keen on simply installing a compliant anti-communist autocrat (basically a fascist) instead of an actual attempt at some "you will love liberal democracy or else"

I think the disconnection goes both ways. Many people view Ukraine and Georgia like it's a Risk game, but simply have the intellectualized morality to understand that killing people is bad, actually, even if you're not there. I'm not implying you support Russia's invasion or anything, but it's a really annoying creeping feeling I've always seen on the left. IMO, it gives me vibes of being the other side of the same coin where people on the right often make excuses for colonialism and imperialism. author: @elliotflores723
text:
18:48 It's interesting that you mention this approach to strategic bombing in Vietnam. During this time, you actually had a pretty "old guard" sort of arrangement in the USAF who very much still had their heads in WW2-styled "bomb them until their industry is dust" mentality. McNamara had to reign in guys like Curtis LeMay who just wanted to drop nukes on Hanoi like it was Japan all over again. The problem - as we know now - is pretty apparent: WW2 isn't Vietnam, and Vietnam wasn't WW2. Even if by conventional measures, the US was doing pretty well against the NVA, the sheer political pressure as well as the war exhaustion of the whole conflict was only growing wider by trying to be so forceful. It didn't help that the RoV in the South had practically collapsed by '63, and what came after was pretty much just a military government which had like, next to no popular support. 

It's easy to see all the parallels with Afghanistan, where the US goes in with their heads in a "Grand Battle, Shock and Awe" sort of mentality that - like in WW2, worked in their previous war (in Kuwait), but falls apart basically as soon as you have to shift gears.

author: @Adonnus100
text:
The interesting question to me is how will US foreign policy evolve over the coming decades? Yes, the Blob is unpunished, but most of the public seems to be sick of the idea of foreign interventions. Out of the three possible paths, that is, one, to stay at home and just be isolationist, two, to intervene everywhere like the Bush administration and the middle ground which is Biden or Obama, obviously option 2 is very unlikely. So that leaves a middle ground or going isolationist. If they go isolationist, they won't defend Taiwan, and since China is the new rival that needs to be contained it would be likely that Taiwan gets defended, unless a true isolationist is in power. 

Within the Donald Trump cohort of the Republican Party there seems to be a faction which does not care at all for the Blob and probably would just do the exact opposite of what they said if they were in power again. The guy himself was too sporadic and unfocused to have any real impact on foreign policy while he was in office, but the message that you *can* deny them seems to have gotten out.

The Biden/moderate camp of the Democratic Party is the exact same as always. However the progressive side of the party is ideologically non-interventionist and very sceptical of these traditional powers and also everything related to big money. So the obvious answer to the question is, which way things go depends on who gets elected, specifically if one of these two more emergent factions can actually win and implement their vision. I think that full isolationism is pretty unlikely since the US is just too big and has certain values in common with the rest of the liberal democratic West which it can't ignore. They tried that in the interwar period and ended up just having to choose sides again.

@what-uy7go That was my impression, having been there. Was there drug use? yah, but there was/is drug use in the US DOD as well. Although the "training" the ANA received was inconsistent, at best. When you have villages risking imprisonment  and death to smuggle Taliban Judges back into the area to adjudicate issues, then smuggling them back out, when they could just go "down the road" (relatively speaking) to the Afghan puppet government, that's a sign you won't win. 

The initial invasion was BS, the Taliban were initially aiding us in locating Al-Qaeda camps to target; then we invaded to install a puppet state. A punitive war against Al-Qaeda, where a good chunk of it's infrastructure and leadership are hiding out in Afghanistan is one thing (especially where the Taliban weren't especially fond of them, they just hadn't given them a reason to go after them); trying to overthrow the legitimate sovereign of a country is another. It's not that the majority of Afghan's cared whether the Taliban were in power or not, they just weren't interested in what we were trying to shove down their throat.

Less than 5 years into that mess, it was already becoming noticed that Afghanistan was becoming like Vietnam, a conflict that was wrong to begin with, and was being dragged out to try and help the "powerful" save face, and to consolidate even more wealth into the hands of a few (warhawks, MIC, ect). author: @jeviosoorishas181
text:
For the record, I want to point out a couple things on foreign policy:

1. When I lived in Massachusetts, there was town called Devens that was not too far away from where I live. It was a town where the biggest driver of economic growth was the Military Barracks. Around the time of the great recession the barracks was shut down, and ever since that period of time, the economy has never recovered. This kind of dilemma is a consistent issue in the United States. Military Spending is not just about bombs, it's about jobs and maintaining the economic foundation of many local governments. The idea of the military industry complex and that American politics is simply driven by the interest of elites with an ideological goal ignores the legacy of the New Deal and WW2 on how America's economy is fundamentally structured. There are multiple webs of interests that extend from the lower to the upper classes of America that drive the often incoherent aspects of US foreign policy, and just like our healthcare system or our welfare system in general, those webs are filled with special interests, activists, unions, lobbyists all fighting for a piece of the pie. 

2. This is the primary issue of Trump. A lot of people liked Trump, the same way a lot of people like a shock to the body as a cure for monotony. However, not understanding the system and how it works, and treating it based off a whim driven by outrage, is how we had the poor reaction to the pandemic, especially compared to other nations that had far less capacity or resources to fight it like we did. An ideology can be wrong and at least understood and criticized, incoherence is what American politics produces generally speaking, because the people have no idea how the system operates and what would have to be given up across the board, so the media gives them the culture war, so they can blame some other groups of people for the existence and incoherence of the system. And in the midst of the confusion the status quo operates, not because it's better, but because there's no coherent alternative and even if it did exist, it would not be propagated by the kind of person who would run for office.

replies.author: @coda-n6u
replies.text:
While China has the potential for growth and surpassing the US, I feel it has immense structural barriers it has to overcome. Many commentators and journalists take China's absolute rise as a given, which seems disingenuous to me. China is aging rapidly, they have few allies on the world stage, they have a largely poorly educated population, a de-industrializing economy, and slowing economic growth. I would not say these problems are insurmountable, but they do stand as an impressive barrier if China is to continue to grow into a world hegemon. 

It will be interesting how the US and western countries factor into the international order if Asia and Africa come to dominate the global economy. We can only hope that they treat us kindly after what we have done to them.

Though I do have to criticize a particular thing, the NATO enlargement thing. See, the problem that us lefties often have with this is that we only take into account two parties in the topic: The US, and Russia. There is no consideration at all given to the simple fact that countries need to WANT to join NATO, or what exactly Russia's "fear" of being "encircled" really actually says without saying it out loud: The reality is that Russia has a history of brutal imperialism towards its neighbours, and the current Russian ruling class clearly still believes in Great Russian Chauvinism and does not accept anything but limited and conditional autonomy for its former imperial victims. replies.text: @TofferKrigsOffer I agree with a lot of your points, but Russia was not *forced* to invade, and even the "ethnic Russian" population did not want them to. The invasion was not "unprovoked," but Russia did not need to.

replies.author: @TofferKrigsOffer
replies.text: @warmlycalculated390 I agree that they were not strictly forced to, but the alternative was pretty intolerable for Russia as well. I long wondered before 2022 why Russia didn't respond militarily or even recognized the independence of the two separatist republics who were openly calling over and over again for Russia to do both. I was surprised in 2022 by the way Russia responded militarily though, was more expecting a 40 000 "peacekeeper" force sent into the Donbas only to calm the situation and make Kiev perhaps more inclined to agreeing to the Minsk 2 agreement or some other diplomatic solution. I guess Russia's patience was over after 8 years of civil war on their border.

replies.author: @warmlycalculated390
replies.text: @TofferKrigsOffer I mean, that "chaos on our border" line doesn't pass the sniff test for Erdogan in Syria, and I'm sure you'd agree that it shouldn't be permitted by the warkhawks in Washington for Mexico, so I don't see why it should be acceptable for Russia. There are many eastern European countries with a large Russian minority. I think the proper model to deal with these was South Ossetia, but Putin really upended what restrainers like me thought of his strategy when he went after the Ukrainian capital. I appreciate how Russia has helped Armenia combat Azeri aggression and what they did in Syria, but this "special military operation" in Ukraine will only succeed in accomplishing in the EXACT OPPOSITE goals that he claims he wanted to accomplish. NATO is stronger than ever, Ukraine is finally mostly united (against Russia) and groups like Azov will have a never-ending supply of radicalized recruits. Crime has also skyrocketed and the endless weapons shipments from the West will ensure the area will be destabilized for years.

replies.author: @TofferKrigsOffer
replies.text:
@warmlycalculated390 The civil war in Syria is not a conflict founded in anti-Turkish sentiment, it is not a conflict between those who want friendly relation with Turkiye and those who want to cancel Turkiye. Same can be said about the cartel issues in Mexico, it is not anti-American in nature and there is no talk about Mexico turning against the US of A in any way. In addition, Turkye has not been deceived diplomatically by encroaching and hostile great power rivals in Syria like Russia was with the Minsk agreements.
When it comes to the capital of Ukraine, Russia never laid proper siege to it, they didn't commit enough men to even get close to doing so, they were also holding back on shelling the city center of Kiev even though they were well within range with artillery and had huge amounts of long range missiles they could use for that (that is if they wanted to harm Ukrainian leadership); the big convoy of 20-30 thousand Russian soldiers that approached Kiev from the north-west were firstly meant to cause disarray and make Ukraine redirect forces from the south-east so it would be easier to break through in the south which they did, it was secondarily meant to intimidate Kiev into taking the option of negotiations seriously in the hope that the conflict could be ended diplomatically before it really started (so a bluff about leveling Kiev). No one had good estimations about how many Russian soldiers were in proximity of Kiev in the convoy to the north-west and approaching from Chernihiv in the north-east, nor how many were actually involved in the Russian military intervention, the early estimation of 180 000 were proven pretty much correct, but many believed there was far more at the time when it happened and therefore a threat to the capital could not be ignored or underestimated, this caused uncertainty and disarray in Ukraine which was imo the main intention of the large convoy and its approach towards Kiev. NATO is not stronger than ever, it's infighting among themselves, it is running out of artillery shells and heavy equipment that it is willing to commit to Ukraine (US has a lot of heavy equipment (not artillery though), but it seems to be holding that back due to an expected war with China in the near future which the US is itching for.); Sweden and Finland is sure being fast-tracked membership (Turkey, Hungary, and Croatia are all skeptical about approving their membership requests, Sweden won't become a member for sure, Finland might perhaps get it in 2023, but Finland is reluctant to go into NATO without Sweden for historical and relational reasons); France is questioning their NATO reliance, and all over Europe anti-NATO protests have exploded in frequency and size. The equipment sent from the west that go missing will mostly flow towards the middle east, Africa and towards Europe, relatively small amounts will likely end up in the arms of Russian crime syndicates (i.e. the destabilization you refer to will affect the west more than Russia I think), and this will be mainly the fault of the west who decided to prolong the war and suffering by pretending Russia's intervention was unprovoked and therefore being absolutists about Ukraine not having to compromise one bit to resolve this 9 year long hot conflict, this conflict with Russia over Ukraine was easily avoidable, but the west has been dead set on it happening for decades, so Russia in the end gave the west what it obviously wanted for so long.

I hope we can continue the conversation in a civil manner even though it gets heated over our disagreements on the matter. 

P.S. I'm not saying Russia is fantastic or something like that; I'm just frustrated by how irrational, arrogant, and ignorant the west has been acting my entire life; and that demonizing Russia while pretending the west is mostly a force of good without a lick of nuance is not the way forward towards resolutions and reconciliation that is needed for a more peaceful tomorrow.

replies.author: @TofferKrigsOffer
replies.text:
@warmlycalculated390 Here's another point I forgot in regards to it not "passing the sniff test for Erdogan in Syria", as you put it. Erdogan has multiple times publicly announced his ambitions and actual plan to launch a ground invasion in Syria, and occupy a 30km strip of northern Syria, he even wowed that he would make it happen. The reason why it hasn't happened is because the US who invaded Syria in 2014 is occupying 1/3 of Syria and has told Turkiye that any Turkish invasion into US occupied Syria is out of the question.

So, my point is that I'm not sure where you are coming from with your sniff test statement, that I'm not sure I understand what you mean with it.

author: @MrSomethingred
text:
I wanna give my two cents (which is really Chomsky's 2¬¢) on the "Vietnam was a failure and domino theory was false".

If we look at why the US entered the war it was to prevent neighbouring Asian countries from "falling" to communism. So they turned Vietnam and Cambodia into a moonscape, hardly capable of sustaining life. And what happened afterwards? None of the other countries turned to communism. The US wasn't really interested in Vietnam, they wanted to make sure that Indonesia, Thailand and every other country doesn't get any ideas. And if you look at the state of Vietnam's neighbours today, from the perspective of the Blob, it was a massive success, Indonesia is frequently described as "Gangster Capitalism" and in Thailand the biggest power structure is the military backed monarchy.

As far as the Blob is concerned, they STOPPED Domino theory. (Which is very different to saying the theory is wrong) therefore the war itself was a success.
